body.p: The June 2012 issue of Nutrition in Clinical Practice is dedicated to the role of nutrition support in cardiovascular and critical care illness. This month’s CAM corner is the first in a 2-part series reviewing the literature on use of complementary and alternative modalities for the prevention and treatment of cardiovascular disease. This month’s issue will focus on diet, whereas the second segment in August will cover mind-body therapies, lifestyle modifications, and nutraceutical supplements.

sec.title: Usage of Complementary and Alternative Medicine for Cardiovascular Health
sec.p: Many patients with cardiovascular diseases employ complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) modalities into their therapeutic regimen. The 2002 National Health Interview Survey analyzed data on CAM use in 10,572 respondents with cardiovascular disease.1 Among those with cardiovascular disease (CVD), 36% had used CAM (excluding prayer) in the previous 12 months. Most, however, who used CAM for their cardiovascular condition perceived the therapies to be helpful (80% for herbs, 94% for mind-body therapies).2 The 2007 National Health Interview Survey analysis compared use of CAM by individuals with CVD (those individuals self-reporting a diagnosis of coronary heart disease; n = 1055), individuals with CVD risk factors (those self-reporting a diagnosis of hypertension [n = 6849] or high serum cholesterol level [n = 5808]), and individuals who self-report as not having CVD or CVD risk factors (n = 22,290).3 Overall, the most common categories of complementary modalities used by individuals with a self-reported diagnosis of CVD or CVD risk factors were natural products and mind-body practices.

sec.title: Alternative Modalities for Cardiovascular Health
sec.p: Many years ago, many facets to cardiovascular health may have seemed to be “alternative” but are staples to the tool box of the healthcare practitioner. For example, encouraging exercise, having a diet low in saturated fats, and using stress reduction techniques are common recommendations provided to patients by preventive cardiologists today. Which modalities have been shown to be helpful?

sec.title: Diet
sec.p: Three main dietary strategies have been shown to have value for primary prevention of CVD: (1) consuming a diet high in fruits, vegetables, nuts, and whole grains rather than refined grain products4; (2) increasing consumption of ω-3 fatty acids from marine and plant sources, including nutrition supplements5; and (3) replacing saturated and trans fats with nonhydrogenated unsaturated fats.6

The Mediterranean diet first began to attract attention after epidemiologic studies showed that Mediterranean people tended to have relatively low rates of CVD. The diet is high in the consumption of olive oil, nuts, vegetable, beans, and legumes; moderate in the consumption of fish, dairy, and alcohol; and low in the consumption of red meat. Although this diet is not considered low fat, much of its health properties may stem from the fact that the fats represented tend to be polyunsaturated fats, which come from fish and some plants, and monounsaturated fats, which come mostly from the olives and nuts. Olives, olive oil and fish are the main sources of this diet’s high concentration of ω-3 fatty acids, which are associated with the primary prevention of CVD. Olive oil and fish oil–rich diets normalize lipoprotein metabolism, reduce oxidative damage, attenuate inflammation, reverse endothelial dysfunction, lower blood pressure, prevent thrombosis, and improve carbohydrate metabolism.7,8 Nordmann et al9 showed in a meta-analysis that the Mediterranean diet improved cardiovascular risk factors (blood pressure, total cholesterol) and inflammatory markers when compared with a control low-fat diet. Singh et al10 showed that an Indio-Mediterranean diet reduced sudden cardiac events. The Mediterranean diet has also been shown to be effective for the secondary prevention of coronary artery disease.11

The DASH (dietary approaches to stop hypertension) diet is high in fruits and vegetables, whole grains, potassium, magnesium, and calcium and has moderate levels of dairy products and meat, and much of its protein is derived from plant sources such as legumes. The DASH diet, widely used for secondary prevention of hypertension, also has a role in the primary prevention of CVD. Fung et al12 followed 88,517 female nurses aged 34–59 years for 24 years. They observed that those who adhered to the DASH diet had a reduced prevalence of fatal and nonfatal myocardial infarctions (relative risk [RR], 0.76) and stroke (RR, 0.89).

Although the Mediterranean diet promotes a balanced consumption of healthy fats, the Dr Dean Ornish diet restricts fat to 15% of total daily caloric intake. His program for preventing CVD includes meditation, exercise, and avoidance of smoking tobacco; this program has shown benefit for the secondary prevention of cardiovascular events with established CVD.13 It also appears that not only the quantity but also the quality of fat plays an important role in the development of CVD. Trans fatty acids (ie, margarine, shortenings) are associated with a dramatic increase in risk for CVD. The relative risk of developing CVD from taking trans fatty acids ranges from 1.14 to 1.93 by a 2% increase in trans fatty acid in the diet.14 Other dietary factors that have been shown to improve CVD risk factors include soy,15 fiber,16 and moderate alcohol consumption.17,18 Diets rich in magnesium and potassium are associated with lower blood pressure and inversely correlated with CVD.19
In summary, a vegetable-based diet that favors monounsaturated fats and ω-3 fatty acids while sparing trans fatty acids may be helpful in preventing CVD.
